title: Speech acts: Constative and performative - Colleen Glenney Boggs

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary distinction between constatives and performatives, as defined by British linguist J. L. Austin?

options.label: A
options.text: Constatives are short sentences, and performatives are long sentences.

options.label: B
options.text: Constatives describe something as true or false, and performatives denote an action.

options.label: C
options.text: Constatives are written, and performatives are spoken.

options.label: D
options.text: Constatives are formal, and performatives are informal.

multiple-choice.question: What type of sentence is the sign "The park closes at 6 p.m." an example of?
What is the primary function of the word "Recycle" on the blue trash bin?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey a message about the environment

options.label: B
options.text: To request people to put their trash into the proper receptacle

options.label: C
options.text: To describe the contents of the trash bin

options.label: D
options.text: To warn people about the consequences of not recycling

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the actions that words can perform, such as ordering, promising, and apologizing?
What is the term used to describe the rules under which a performative can be enacted?
What is an example of a felicity condition that must be met for a performative to be enacted?

options.label: A
options.text: The performative must be spoken loudly

options.label: B
options.text: The performative must be written in capital letters

options.label: C
options.text: The performative must have proper authority

options.label: D
options.text: The performative must be repeated three times

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a speech act that can be performed with the words "I do"?
Why might the words "I name this gazebo 'The Mayor's Pizza Palace'" be effective when spoken by the mayor, but not when spoken by a normal passerby?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mayor is louder than the passerby

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mayor has proper authority

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mayor is more persuasive than the passerby

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mayor is more creative than the passerby

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a consequence that might occur if someone fails to follow a performative, such as "No running"?

options.label: C
options.text: They might have to apologize and promise to never run again

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary power of words, as demonstrated by the examples of constatives and performatives?

options.label: C
options.text: To denote actions and change the world

title: The most groundbreaking scientist you've never heard of - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What was Nicolas Steno's profession before he became an anatomist?
What significant discovery did Steno make while studying animal skulls?

options.label: A
options.text: He found a duct that sends saliva to the mouth.

options.label: B
options.text: He discovered the pineal gland in animals.

options.label: C
options.text: He found a way to cure the plague.

options.label: D
options.text: He discovered the seat of the soul.

multiple-choice.question: Whose idea did Steno refute regarding the pineal gland?
What was Steno's method of scientific inquiry?

options.label: A
options.text: He relied on ancient texts and Aristotelian metaphysics.

options.label: B
options.text: He used Cartesian deductions to guide his research.

options.label: D
options.text: He relied on speculation and rationalization.

multiple-choice.question: What did Steno discover about the formation of gallstones?

options.label: A
options.text: They form through erosion and sedimentation.

options.label: B
options.text: They obey molding principles similar to those in the goldsmith trade.

options.label: C
options.text: They are formed through plate tectonics.

options.label: D
options.text: They are created through uniformitarian processes.

multiple-choice.question: What did Steno realize about tongue stones while dissecting a shark?

options.label: A
options.text: They were formed through erosion and sedimentation.

options.label: B
options.text: They were shark teeth from ancient sharks.

options.label: C
options.text: They were created through plate tectonics.

options.label: D
options.text: They were rocks that fell from the sky.

multiple-choice.question: What concept did Steno help establish through his study of rock layers?
Who built upon Steno's work to develop the idea of uniformitarianism?
What was the significance of Steno's work in relation to the age of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: He estimated the Earth to be 6000 years old.

options.label: B
options.text: He proved the Earth was 4.5 billion years old.

options.label: C
options.text: His work led to the realization that the Earth was much older than previously thought.

options.label: D
options.text: He had no impact on the understanding of the Earth's age.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Steno's work on the development of evolutionary theory?

options.label: A
options.text: He disproved the theory of evolution.

options.label: B
options.text: He had no impact on the development of evolutionary theory.

options.label: C
options.text: His work laid the groundwork for Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.

options.label: D
options.text: He was the first to propose the theory of evolution.

title: Was Leonardo da Vinci dyslexic?

options.text: Because he was trying to confuse his readers

options.text: Because he was following a medieval tradition

options.label: B
options.text: A learning disability that affects only writing skills

options.label: C
options.text: An inherited learning disability that impairs reading and writing skills

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was trying to create a code

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was left-handed and didn't want to smudge the ink

options.label: C
options.text: Because his brain was wired to do so

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: There is no significant difference between the groups

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: The number of words it has

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of a writing system

options.text: The fact that it has grammar and changes over time

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Having a single, unchanging verb form

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Elvish is more widely spoken and used

options.label: C

title: Your genes are not your fate - Dean Ornish

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one way to change our genes?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between our genes and our fate?

title: Birth of a nickname - John McWhorter

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "nickname"?

title: The physics of human sperm vs. the physics of the sperm whale

options.label: B
options.text: Because water molecules are too small

options.label: C
options.text: Because water molecules are too large and numerous, making it like swimming in a pool of people

options.label: B
options.text: Only the speed of the swimmer

options.label: C
options.text: Properties like the size of the swimmer, its speed, the density of the fluid, and the viscosity of the fluid

options.label: C
options.text: By using adaptations such as deforming the shape of their paddle or winding their paddles like a cork screw

options.label: D
options.text: By waiting for the water to move them

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Gravity and the human body - Jay Buckey

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the human body when it is in a state of weightlessness for an extended period?

options.label: A
options.text: The body gains bone and muscle mass.

options.label: B
options.text: The body loses bone and muscle mass.

options.label: D
options.text: The body only loses bone mass.

multiple-choice.question: Which muscles are most affected by weightlessness?

options.label: B
options.text: Postural muscles that work against gravity

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the heart and blood vessels are affected by weightlessness?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have to work harder to pump blood

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have to work against gravity to keep blood flowing to the head

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not needed in space

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are affected by the lack of oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What system is responsible for maintaining balance in the human body?
What happens to the balance system when a person is in a state of weightlessness?

options.label: D
options.text: It adapts to the new environment

multiple-choice.question: Why do people who spend extended periods in space have trouble maintaining their balance when they return to Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their balance system has been damaged

options.label: B
options.text: Because their balance system has adapted to the weightless environment

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have lost muscle mass

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have lost bone mass

options.text: They put a patch over the eye of a kitten

options.label: C
options.text: They studied the brain of a person who was born blind

options.label: D
options.text: They studied the brain of a person who was born with a rare neurological disorder

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the experiment conducted by Hubel and Wiesel?

options.label: B
options.text: The kitten's brain did not develop normally

options.label: D
options.text: The kitten's brain was not affected

multiple-choice.question: What does the experiment conducted by Hubel and Wiesel suggest about the development of the brain in a weightless environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They may have trouble maintaining their balance
